verses.text: After two full years had passed, Pharaoh dreamed that he was standing by the Nile river.
verses.comment: This verse connects to Joseph's imprisonment and the delay before his rise to power, highlighting God's providence and timing.

verses.text: Suddenly, out of the river there came up seven cows, beautiful and well-fed, and they grazed among the reeds.
verses.comment: The Nile is a symbol of Egypt’s life and fertility; the seven cows foreshadow years of abundance.

verses.text: Then seven other cows, ugly and thin, came up out of the river after them and stood beside the other cows on the riverbank.
verses.comment: These thin cows will represent famine—God reveals both blessing and trial, foreshadowing judgment and redemption.

verses.text: The ugly and thin cows ate the seven beautiful and well-fed cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
verses.comment: The dream vividly reveals coming hardship overtaking prosperity, a test of faith and wisdom.

verses.text: Pharaoh fell asleep again and had a second dream: Seven heads of grain, fat and healthy, grew on a single stalk.
verses.comment: Dream repetition emphasizes certainty; also see Joseph’s double dreams in Gen 37. God’s messages are often confirmed through repetition.

verses.text: After them, seven heads of grain, thin and scorched by the east wind, sprouted up.
verses.comment: The east wind, often symbolic of destruction (Ex. 10:13), foreshadows the devastation of famine.

verses.text: The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven fat and full heads. Then Pharaoh woke up a second time, and it was a dream.
verses.comment: The repeated pattern shows God’s sovereignty and purpose in history (Dan. 2:28).

verses.text: In the morning, Pharaoh's spirit was troubled. He sent and called for all the magicians of Egypt and all its wise men. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but none could interpret them for him.
verses.comment: Human wisdom is inadequate without God's revelation. This moment prepares for God's intervention through His chosen servant, anticipating Christ’s role as the true Interpreter and Savior.

verses.text: Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, 'I remember my sins today.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s earlier kindness is finally remembered. God exalts the humble in due time (1 Pet. 5:6).

verses.text: Pharaoh was angry with his servants and put me in the custody of the captain of the guard, me and the chief baker.
verses.comment: Recounting past events shows the unfolding of God’s plan through apparent misfortunes.

verses.text: We each had a dream on the same night, he and I, and each dream had its own meaning.
verses.comment: Dreams serve as instruments for divine purposes. God speaks to His people in many ways (Num. 12:6).

verses.text: There was with us a young Hebrew, a servant of the captain of the guard. We told him our dreams, and he interpreted them for us, giving each man his own interpretation.
verses.comment: Joseph’s gift, given by God, highlights His ability to raise up the humble and use them as instruments for salvation.

verses.text: Just as he interpreted for us, so it happened: I was restored to my office, and the other man was hanged.
verses.comment: Joseph’s words were fulfilled exactly, confirming that his wisdom is from God, prefiguring Christ as the true prophet (Deut. 18:15).

verses.text: Then Pharaoh sent and called for Joseph, and they quickly brought him out of the pit. He shaved, changed his clothes, and came before Pharaoh.
verses.comment: Joseph’s rise from prison to the royal court is a type of resurrection, foreshadowing Christ’s victory (Phil. 2:8-11).

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'I have had a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it. But I have heard it said about you that when you hear a dream you can interpret it.'
verses.comment: Joseph is distinguished for his spiritual gift rather than worldly wisdom.

verses.text: Joseph answered Pharaoh, 'It is not in me; God will give Pharaoh a favorable answer.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s humility credits God alone, teaching reliance on divine grace, a principle foundational for leadership in the church.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'In my dream I was standing on the bank of the Nile,'
verses.comment: The Nile again sets the dream firmly within Egypt’s context and prosperity.

verses.text: 'Suddenly, seven cows came up out of the river, plump and healthy, and grazed among the reeds.'
verses.comment: The repetition emphasizes the abundance to come.

verses.text: 'Then seven other cows came up after them, poor and very ugly and thin, unlike any I had ever seen in all the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Extreme famine and suffering are depicted—God uses even harsh circumstances to fulfill His will.

verses.text: 'The thin, ugly cows ate up the seven plump cows that came up first,'
verses.comment: The imagery of consumption reinforces the totality of coming famine.

verses.text: 'Yet when they had eaten them, no one would have known, for they still looked as thin and ugly as at the beginning. Then I woke up.'
verses.comment: The famine's severity is underscored—consuming all abundance, yet giving no sign of relief.

verses.text: 'I also saw in my dream seven heads of grain, full and good, growing on a single stalk.'
verses.comment: Parallels the earlier dream, affirming the divine origin and gravity of the message.

verses.text: 'Then seven thin and scorched heads grew up after them.'
verses.comment: The East wind as a biblical symbol often represents judgment (Jonah 4:8).

verses.text: 'The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven good heads. I told this to the magicians, but no one could explain it to me.'
verses.comment: The inability of Egypt’s wise men prepares for a greater, divinely empowered wisdom that prefigures the wisdom given to Church leadership (Jas. 1:5).

verses.text: Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, 'Pharaoh's dreams are one. God has revealed to Pharaoh what He is about to do.'
verses.comment: All dreams have a unified meaning from God. Interpretation is an authoritative function, later symbolizing the unified teaching authority of the people of God.

verses.text: 'The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good heads of grain are seven years; the dreams are one.'
verses.comment: A clear and direct connection between the dream and God's unfolding plan.

verses.text: 'The seven thin and ugly cows that came up after them are seven years, as are the seven thin heads of grain scorched by the east wind. They will be seven years of famine.'
verses.comment: Again, God’s sovereignty is affirmed over both plenty and want (Job 1:21).

verses.text: 'It is as I have told Pharaoh: God has shown Pharaoh what He is about to do.'
verses.comment: The revelation to Pharaoh, a gentile, hints at the universality of God’s plan for salvation (Acts 10:34).

verses.text: 'Seven years of great abundance are coming throughout all the land of Egypt,'
verses.comment: God’s kindness is given before coming judgment, providing hope in times of trial.

verses.text: 'But after them will come seven years of famine, and all the abundance in Egypt will be forgotten; the famine will consume the land.'
verses.comment: Scripture consistently testifies that earthly abundance is fleeting (Matt. 6:19).

verses.text: 'And the abundance will be forgotten in the land because of the famine that follows, for it will be very severe.'
verses.comment: A call to trust in God more than in temporal blessings.

verses.text: 'Since the dream was repeated to Pharaoh twice, that means the matter is firmly established by God, and God will bring it about soon.'
verses.comment: God confirms important revelations for certainty, prefiguring later definitive teachings for the people of God (2 Cor. 13:1).

verses.text: 'Therefore, let Pharaoh select a man who is discerning and wise, and set him over the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: The need for divinely-appointed leadership is introduced, foreshadowing the apostolic model of governance (Acts 6:3).

verses.text: 'Let Pharaoh do this: appoint officers over the land, and collect a fifth of the produce of the land of Egypt during the seven plentiful years.'
verses.comment: Joseph's administrative plan shows wisdom in stewardship, a virtue emphasized for leaders among God’s people.

verses.text: 'Let them gather all the food from these good years that are coming and store up grain under Pharaoh’s control to be kept in the cities for food.'
verses.comment: Centralized storage ensures provision for all, reflecting the call to unity and sharing within the faith community (Acts 2:44–45).

verses.text: 'That food shall be reserved for the land for the seven years of famine that are to come upon Egypt, so that the land will not perish during the famine.'
verses.comment: Joseph ensures salvation through wise preparation, a foreshadow of spiritual preparation for trials.

verses.text: This proposal was good in the eyes of Pharaoh and all his servants.
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is recognized even by those outside the covenant people.

verses.text: Pharaoh said to his servants, 'Can we find anyone like this, a man in whom is the spirit of God?'
verses.comment: Pharaoh recognizes the Spirit at work in Joseph, anticipating later gifts of the Holy Spirit in God’s leaders (Isa. 11:2).

verses.text: So Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'Since God has made all this known to you, there is no one so discerning and wise as you are.'
verses.comment: True discernment is a divine gift. The people of God are called to seek such wisdom in their leaders.

verses.text: 'You shall be over my house, and all my people shall order themselves by your word. Only with respect to the throne will I be greater than you.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s unique authority is established, pointing to the special leadership office, with one above all, a foreshadowing of singular leadership in the church (John 21:17).

verses.text: And Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'See, I have set you over all the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Joseph, in effect, becomes Egypt’s savior, anticipating the way the Redeemer will be exalted to save the world.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh took the signet ring from his hand and put it on Joseph’s hand. He dressed him in fine linen garments and put a gold chain around his neck.
verses.comment: The signet ring symbolizes full authority (Est. 8:2). Joseph’s exaltation points to the dignity of those raised up by God.

verses.text: He made him ride in the second chariot, and they shouted before him, 'Bow the knee!' So he set him over all the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: All pay homage to Joseph. Bowing prefigures every knee bowing to Christ (Phil. 2:9–10).

verses.text: Moreover, Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'I am Pharaoh, and without your consent no one shall lift hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: This statement underscores Joseph’s delegated authority, reflecting the biblical theme of mediation and stewardship.

verses.text: Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath-paneah. He gave him Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, as his wife. And Joseph went through all the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Joseph’s new name and wife mark full acceptance in Egypt. Marriage to the priest’s daughter prefigures the uniting of all nations in the plan of God (Eph. 2:13–16).

verses.text: Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt. Joseph went out from Pharaoh’s presence and traveled throughout the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Joseph began his ministry at age 30, as Jesus did. This parallel is a high point of typology.

verses.text: During the seven years of abundance, the earth produced bountifully.
verses.comment: God’s blessings on the earth are evident. The land yields in response to divine favor.

verses.text: He collected all the food produced in those seven years in Egypt and stored it in the cities, placing in each city the food from the fields around it.
verses.comment: Joseph’s wise administration preserves life, anticipating the faithful stewardship required of God’s leaders.

verses.text: Joseph stored up grain in great quantities, like the sand of the sea, until he stopped measuring, for it could not be counted.
verses.comment: An echo of God’s promise to Abraham about descendants—famine cannot outnumber God’s provision.

verses.text: Before the years of famine came, two sons were born to Joseph by Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.
verses.comment: Joseph’s sons become tribes in Israel, showing God's inclusion of those once estranged.

verses.text: Joseph named the firstborn Manasseh. 'For,' he said, 'God has made me forget all my hardship and all my father's house.'
verses.comment: Manasseh means 'causing to forget.' God brings healing and new purpose.

verses.text: The second he named Ephraim, for he said, 'God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.'
verses.comment: Ephraim means 'fruitful.' Joseph’s deliverance foreshadows spiritual fruitfulness born of suffering (John 12:24).

verses.text: The seven years of abundance in the land of Egypt came to an end.
verses.comment: Everything unfolds as God has revealed. The cycle of plenty and trial continues in salvation history.

verses.text: Then the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. There was famine in all lands, but in all the land of Egypt there was bread.
verses.comment: Joseph, as provider of bread, prefigures Christ as the Bread of Life (John 6:35).

verses.text: When all the land of Egypt was suffering from hunger, the people cried out to Pharaoh for food. Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, 'Go to Joseph. What he says to you, do.'
verses.comment: Pharaoh commands obedience to Joseph alone, paralleling Mary’s directive, 'Do whatever he tells you,' at Cana. There is an authority and mediation in access to God’s gifts.

verses.text: So when the famine was over all the land, Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians, for the famine was severe in the land.
verses.comment: Joseph as distributor of bread has strong Christological connections—God’s agent making salvation available to all.

verses.text: Moreover, all the earth came to Egypt to Joseph to buy grain, because the famine was severe over all the earth.
verses.comment: The nations come to Joseph—the type of true mediator and savior—foreshadowing when all nations will be drawn to God’s chosen one (Isa. 2:2; Matt. 8:11).
